readme.html.icon: <svg class="svg-icon lucide-file" stroke-linejoin="round" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-width="2" stroke="currentColor" fill="none" viewBox="0 0 24 24" height="24" width="24" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M15 2H6a2 2 0 0 0-2 2v16a2 2 0 0 0 2 2h12a2 2 0 0 0 2-2V7Z"></path><path d="M14 2v4a2 2 0 0 0 2 2h4"></path></svg>
readme.html.description:
This is a demo vault for all Obsidian things that KillyMXI decides / finds time to share with the world. 2025-10-21 demo vault first published
added Rolling calendar views (using Datacore plugin) list threading CSS will be moved here at a later date
for now it is still available in the gist
README this note
Rolling calendar description of my rolling calendar views assets/ screenshots, etc. journal/ dummy daily notes for any demonstration purposes lorem ipsum/ dummy notes for any demonstration purposes obsidian/ (note: different from .obsidian/) is where I put all custom machinery such as script, templates, etc. datacore/
contains all code of my custom Datacore components and necessary utilities

rolling-calendar.html.title: Rolling calendar
rolling-calendar.html.icon: <svg class="svg-icon lucide-file" stroke-linejoin="round" stroke-linecap="round" stroke-width="2" stroke="currentColor" fill="none" viewBox="0 0 24 24" height="24" width="24" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg"><path d="M15 2H6a2 2 0 0 0-2 2v16a2 2 0 0 0 2 2h12a2 2 0 0 0 2-2V7Z"></path><path d="M14 2v4a2 2 0 0 0 2 2h4"></path></svg>
rolling-calendar.html.description:
I think that the calendar design where a year is broken into month has serious flaws. The time goes on and doesn't care about how you slice it. We should stop bringing the constraints of physical objects (mass-produced paper calendars) into digital world, where we can achieve much more.Long time ago I figured that I can create custom continuous calendars for important time intervals and print them out on paper, to write on them. I was doing these from time to time even up until recent years when I discovered Obsidian. And may even still do in specific situations in the future.Naturally, as my system of Obsidian daily notes was evolving, I needed a similar overview of a time window around current day, where I could see on the calendar everything that links to daily notes. Back then (in 2023) I used Dataview plugin. Because of some plugins' UX flaws, I didn't feel like my solution is good enough to recommend to wide audience.Around the same time, I realized I pretty certainly have ADHD. That explains some things about my relation with time, memory and other things. Good visualization is of vital importance to me - putting upcoming and past events on a "map" helps to augment memory and time perception with spatial perception...Now, Datacore is available for everyone, and it allows much better ergonomics of created components. So I've rewritten my calendar, with some cleanup and improvements, and can present as something that is easy to adopt and adapt by almost any Obsidian user.Do I see this as a dedicated plugin? A dedicated plugin would be way more rigid compared to a Datacore component that can be modified any time according to shifting personal requirements. The only true organization system is the one that can grow and evolve with you. But I also would be happy to see less of bad calendars, including in plugins, if my creation can show the path to more ergonomic design. Datacore plugin following files placed in the vault: obsidian/datacore/calendarDay.jsx obsidian/datacore/calendars.css obsidian/datacore/luxonUtils.js obsidian/datacore/rollingDayCalendar.jsx obsidian/datacore/rollingWeekCalendar.jsx Note: there is currently no way for Datacore components to use relative paths. Paths inside files might need to be edited according to your vault organizational structure if you put them in a different place.Intent: to see few weeks ahead and behind from current (or specified) day.It is like your monthly wall calendar with a room for notes, except you will never be in a situation when tomorrow or yesterday is on another page and can't be seen.And it uses note linking and properties to be a live presentation of all things that you choose to be aware of, without any convoluted vault organization.
For each day cell contents see the Calendar day section below.How to use:```datacorejsx const { RollingWeekCalendar } = await dc.require("obsidian/datacore/rollingWeekCalendar.jsx"); return function View() { // with all defaults: // return <RollingWeekCalendar /> // with explicit properties: return <RollingWeekCalendar date={"2025-10-21"} firstWeekOffset={-2} lastWeekOffset={2} minWeeks={2} maxWeeks={7} weekStart={1} showControls={true} /> } ``` What you get:(Note: it is only interactive when opened in Obsidian. On the web you either see it static or as a code block like above. Web preview also doesn't show note properties.)
6MonOct7Tue8Wed9Thu10Fri11Sat12Sun13141516171819üõç

Screenshot: screenshot of rolling week calendar.pngIntent: to see few days ahead and behind from current (or specified) day.It was a stepping stone in the development of rolling week calendar - for me that's the main reason why it is here. But it might be useful for someone else.
For each day cell contents see the Calendar day section below.How to use:```datacorejsx const { RollingDayCalendar } = await dc.require("obsidian/datacore/rollingDayCalendar.jsx"); return function View() { // with all defaults: // return <RollingDayCalendar /> // with explicit properties: return <RollingDayCalendar date={"2025-10-21"} firstDayOffset={-2} lastDayOffset={4} minDays={3} maxDays={10} showControls={true} /> } ``` What you get:(Note: it is only interactive when opened in Obsidian. On the web you either see it static or as a code block like above. Web preview also doesn't show note properties.)

Screenshot: screenshot of rolling day calendar.pngBoth types of rolling calendar use the same component for individual day.It has following features: date (top left) day of the month links to the daily note if it exists daily notes are assumed to have the YYYY-MM-DD name format the day (specified day, today by default) - bold month name (top center) only shown for the first day of each month on screen note area (top right) intended to only fit couple emojis - think what makes most sense for you üìç if the daily note contains calendarNote property - it will be put here üìç if any notes linking to the daily note contain calendarNote property - all will be appended here as well, as links those links won't be put into inlinks list below intent: most common recurring tasks that don't require extra words, to free up the space in inlinks area for anything more special inlinks area links to notes that link to this daily note (regardless of whether the daily note itself exist or not) daily notes of one day before and after are not included pops out on hover to show long titles there is no way to expand outside of the code block though, afaik it seems preferable when Page preview setting "Require Ctrl to trigger on hover" is enabled - to avoid some screen space occlusion full note paths in tooltips border existing/non-existing daily notes - solid/dashed borders today - extra outline üìç if the daily note or any note linking to it contains calendarColor property - its value will be set as the border color use inlink colors sparingly - there is no way to resolve color conflicts weekday today - more contrast color the weekday (same weekday as specified day) - bold Some CSS classes explained (for custom styling):

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_showCustomIcons.description: Show custom icons for files and folders

info_showDefaultFolderIcons.description: Show a default icon of a folder for every folder in the tree

info_showDefaultFileIcons.description: Show a default icon of a file for every file in the tree

info_defaultFolderIcon.description: The icon to use for folders. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultFileIcon.description: The icon to use for files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultMediaIcon.description: The icon to use for media files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_exposeStartingPath.description: Whether or not to show the current file in the file tree when the page is first loaded

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_minCollapseDepth.description: Only allow outline items to be collapsed if they are at least this many levels deep in the tree.

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.

info_allowResizing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be resized

info_allowCollapsing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be collapsed

info_rightDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the right sidebar

info_leftDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the left sidebar

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_sourcePath.description: The local path to the source .html file which will be included.

info_allowFoldingLists.description: Whether or not to allow lists to be folded

info_allowFoldingHeadings.description: Whether or not to allow headings to be folded

info_siteUrl.description: The url that this site will be hosted at

info_authorName.description: The name of the author of the site
